ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIMARY PRODUCTION
(Government Policy)


    1. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what is the current policy of the Government on primary production and whether there are specific plans to achieve self-sufficiency in pork, poultry, eggs and other primary produce.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the Government's policy to achieve self-sufficiency in pork, poultry, eggs and other primary produce. I have explained in reply to a previous Question how an attempt to achieve self-sufficiency in pork has led to great harm in the form of environmental pollution and high cost to consumers. All producers of poultry, eggs and other primary produce must compete with imports if they want to survive.

    It is better that we earn incomes in producing goods and services in which we have a competitive advantage over others and buy from other countries what we need with the money we earn.

CITIZENSHIP APPLICATIONS
(Refusals)


    2. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in the years 1981-83 (a) how many applications for citizenship had been refused; and (b) how many of such refusals had been endorsed by the Citizenship Advisory Committee.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, from 1981 to 1983, 35,908 new applications for citizenship were received. This was in addition to the number of cases carried forward. In the same period, a total of 29,548 applications were approved and 13,149 were refused. All the applications refused had been endorsed by the Citizenship Advisory Committee. The

number of refusals each year was as follows: 

      Year           No. of Refusals



      1981                  5,202

      1982                  6,887

      1983                  1,060


     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, supplementary question for the Minister. Perhaps would he tell us who comprise the Citizenship Advisory Committee?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Citizenship Advisory Committee is constituted under Article 18, clause 2 of the Third Schedule to the Constitution of Singapore. The present members of the Committee are Mr G. Ramachandran, Encik Mohamed Ismail bin Haji Pitchay and Mr Philip Liau.

REGISTERED SOCIETIES
(Non-citizen officials)


    3. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will inform the House of the number of registered societies which have non-citizen officials and whether such a situation is acceptable to the Government.

     Prof. Jayakumar (for the Minister of Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 1st March this year, there were 3,133 registered societies. Of these, 617 or 20% had non-Singapore citizens on their management committees. Only political societies are restricted to Singapore citizens.

    Membership of non-political societies is not confined to Singapore citizens. There are adequate safeguards to prevent foreigners from making use of these societies for unlawful purposes or for purposes against the national interest. Groups seeking registration are required to state the objects of the proposed society and to provide the names and particulars of the pro-tem committee members. Each application is carefully considered to ensure that registration is not detrimental to national interest. Registered societies are also required to submit returns stating the names and particulars of persons elected each year to the management committee. Any society used for unlawful purposes or

Column: 1181

for purposes incompatible with its objects and rules can be dissolved. There is, therefore, no compelling reason at present to restrict membership of all societies to Singapore citizens. Such a move would deprive societies, such as charitable and civic organizations, of the useful contributions made by non-citizen officials.

NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS


    4. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked Mr Ong Teng Cheong, Minister without portfolio, what is the justification for celebrating Singapore's National Day this year from June to December and what the celebrations are expected to cost the taxpayers.

     The Minister without Portfolio (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker Sir, there is no plan to celebrate Singapore's National Day this year from June to December. So the question of the Member is irrelevant.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was an announcement -

     Mr Speaker: I would like to have your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister what is it that he plans to celebrate from June to December this year which was announced in the papers?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as usual, the Member got his facts wrong. Nevertheless, perhaps I will help him with the question. He wants to know what is the justification for celebrating 25 years of nation building this year from June to December. Is that right?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I want to know what you are celebrating?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: What is your question? Are you talking about National Day celebrations or you are talking about whatever we are celebrating? We have a lot of celebrations from June to December this year. I am trying to help you with your question. I believe what you want to know is the justification for celebrating Singapore's 25 years of nation building this year from June to December. This is what I

Column: 1182

announced not very long ago to the press. Is that your question?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, did he not announce - and it has been repeated ad nauseam in the papers - that we are celebrating our nationhood? Is that what we are celebrating? Maybe if we are not celebrating that, then may I know what is it that we are celebrating?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question submitted by the Member is about National Day Celebration this year. Anyway, I will explain why we are celebrating 25 years of nation building this year, not what is printed in the Order Paper here.

    Singapore achieved internal self-government on 3rd June, 1959 when the Singapore (Constitution) Order-in-Council came into operation. The process of nation building has continued unabated since, and much progress has been made in the economic, social and defence spheres. Singaporeans have every reason to look back to the past with pride as they contributed to these achievements. It is therefore fining that Singaporeans celebrate 25 years of nation building.

    The celebrations will begin with an SBC show at the City Hall on 2nd or 3rd of June and end with a month-long National Exhibition in November/December this year. National Day is one of the Celebration events. The other events, including sporting items, exhibitions, variety shows and parades, are all aimed to allow for mass participation. Singaporeans can be proud of what they have achieved over the past 25 years, and they have every right to rejoice and to participate in the celebration.

    Most of the events are annual affairs to be adapted and tailored to fit in with the National Celebration. Private organizations are encouraged to plan and finance their own programmes or sponsor some of the national events.

    The Government is expected to spend a net amount of $11 million on account of the National Celebrations. The bulk of this sum, about $8 million, will go towards meeting the cost of a month-long National Exhibition to be held at the World Trade

Column: 1183

Centre. The balance is for organizing shows, sporting events, parades, publications, publicity and the printing of promotional materials.

    The National Exhibition will be the largest ever held in Singapore. It will occupy three exhibition halls and an open exhibition area totalling 34,000 sq metres. It will feature the physical transformation of Singapore with emphasis on the tangible developments of the last 25 years and of the things to come.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether Singaporeans have been asked to celebrate nation building or 25 years of domination by the PAP?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, I do not wish to repeat what has been said. What V!e have achieved over the past 25 years is something that Singaporeans can be proud of and Singaporeans will be celebrating 25 years of nation building this year.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister what is his basis for this glib statement that Singaporeans are all very anxious - it appears from his pronouncements that Singaporeans are all ready and eager to celebrate this 25 years of nation building at a cost of $11 million. May I ask what is there for them to celebrate?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe all Singaporeans have the right, as anybody else, to celebrate their National Day, or nation building. If the Member for Anson does not wish to celebrate nation building and if he does not feel that he has contributed anything to nation building for the last 25 years, by all means, he does not have to take part. There is no need for him to behave like a sour grape.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not a question of sour grapes. Mr Speaker, Sir, do the taxpayers have a say or not? May I ask the Minister, do the taxpayers have a say in this expense of $11 million? If they have a say, are you going to give them a say? The only way that you can give them a say is to have a referendum for this expenditure of $11 million.

TELOK BLANGAH CRESCENT
(Replacement of faulty lifts)


    6. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for National Development why the old and faulty lifts in Telok Blangah Crescent have not been replaced in spite of repeated representations ma de by residents to the Housing and Development Board officials.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board plans to replace a total of 160 old and problematic lifts in its various housing estates with priority given to older lifts which are most prone to breakdown. The 66 problematic lifts in Telok Blangah Crescent are, on average, about 10 years old. They are scheduled to be replaced from December 1984. Replacement work will take six to seven months.

COMPUTER COURSES IN COMMERCIAL SCHOOLS
(Upgrading of teaching standards)


    7. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry whether the Ministry of Finance or the National Computer Board has any specific plans to upgrade or regulate the standard of teaching of the commercial

Column: 1185

schools which offer computer courses, in particular those which prepare the students to sit for examinations leading to certification or professional qualifications.

     The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, there are 12 commercial schools which train students for the joint National Computer Board - British Computer Society (NCB-BCS) professional computer examinations. These schools, like all other commercially-run schools, are required to register under the Education Act which prescribes that such schools must have proper facilities and qualified teachers.

    The success rate of commercial school candidates in the NCB-BCS examinations has been relatively low. For example, only 14.8% of these candidates passed the 1983 Part I examinations as compared with a 37% success rate among candidates employed at Government computer installations. According to the BCS examiners, one of the main reasons for the lower success rate of commercial school candidates is that many of them are over-ambitious. More than 60% attempted all papers at one sifting as compared with 35% for UK candidates. Moreover, many candidates have relatively little working experience and, therefore, have insufficient knowledge of the applications of computer technology and data processing methods in business and industry. As the National Computer Board has a statutory responsibility to establish and maintain standards of computer education in Singapore, it is closely monitoring the performance of all candidates sitting for professional computer examinations, including those from the commercial schools. The NCB is of the view that the teaching standards in the commercial schools need to be upgraded. Towards this end, NCB will be organizing a seminar for instructors of these schools to upgrade their teaching skills and thereby improve the success rate of candidates. Further measures will be taken as and when necessary.

Column: 1186

PRICE-FIXING ACTIVITIES
(Legislation to curb)


    8. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry whether the Ministry of Trade and Industry has made any progress in the preparation of legislation to prohibit the formation of cartels and to curb price-fixing activities.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Trade and Industry has made further progress in the preparation of legislation to prevent price-fixing by trade associations. The Ministry has completed a study of legislation on restrictive trade practices in other countries. Arising from this study, the Ministry has drafted a Bill which is now being discussed with the Attorney-General's Chambers and other Government bodies.

    As my Minister has said in the Budget Debate last year, legislation on restrictive trade practices are intricate and complex. It has taken countries like the United Kingdom, Australia, Japan and the United States of America, many years to draft and o refine the system of legislation to make hem comprehensive in scope and practicable in enforcement. Similarly, we should take great care in the drafting of our own legislation in order not to disrupt the free market mechanism that has been the basis for our economic well-being. Nevertheless, I would like to assure the Member that my Ministry is as concerned as he is with the problem and will introduce the Bill as soon as it is ready.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE

FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 19 TO 31ST MARCH, 1985

2.50 pm

    Head K (cont) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March 1984],

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head K be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead KB-01 of the Main Estimates." - [Mr Rohan bin Kamis].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Sir, first, let me separate the substance from the form. I wish to recapitulate the points raised by my colleagues and information sought by them. They have raised eight points altogether:

    1. Total defence.

    2. Rationale for the extension of the Reserve cycle from 10 to 13 years. Would it not inconvenience the employers?

    3. Criteria for enlistment into National Service.

    4. What has been done by the SAF to improve the quality of its officers so that they could cope with the demands of a modern, technically sophisticated and professionally competent force, and questions on upgrading of permanent staff and the welfare schemes for regular officers.

    5. What is the status of the drug problem in SAF?

    6. Requirement to submit medical certificates within 24 hours.

    7. Search and rescue.

    8. SAF Boys' School.

    Let me deal with the first item, which is total defence. Why total defence, the question was asked. When Singapore became independent in 1965, the primary problem was getting a credible military defence capability quickly. The problem became most urgent when the British announced their pull-out East of Suez in 1967. So National Service was introduced in 1967 and the SAF was formed. It took many years for Singaporeans to accept National Service as a way of life. Three to four years ago the public education effort on Defence

Column: 1188

moved away from full-time National Service to concentrate on the role of reservists, particularly the fact that these are front-line fighting troops and that the better of them would have to be put to higher level of appointments in the Reserve. So we moved from National Service to concentrate on the reservists. But we all know that a military attack on Singapore is not the only means by which Singapore can fall to an aggressor. Public morale and confidence have to be boosted with the knowledge that a civilian population is organized to cope with emergencies even when the younger and physically more capable men are mobilized for SAF service. Hence, civil defence.

    Also, due to a lack of natural resources and a small population, our economy must be organized to withstand external pressures as well as internal pressures that can be brought about by the mobilization of men and equipment from the private sector. Hence, economic defence.

    As a multi-racial society, Singapore can be a fertile ground for mischievous elements to stir up problems on account of race, religion or culture. Hence, the need for social defence, the need to organize communities within housing estates, like RCs, CCCs, community centres and so on.

    But undergirding it all is the need for Singaporeans to be willing to stand up for themselves, Hence, psychological defence.

    Having spent many years to educate the general public concerning military defence, first, concerning fulltime national servicemen and then reservists, we feel that it is now time to cover the other potential weak spots in Singapore's security. Hence, the mass effort on civil defence starting last year, and greater effort this year to educate the public on total defence. Otherwise we, the Singaporeans, can be caught unawares and Singapore can go down without an aggressor even having to mount a military campaign against Singapore because we are not prepared psychologically, socially, and in the fields of economics and civil defence.

Column: 1189



    I will now move on to explain briefly the rationale for extending the Reserve cycle from 10 to 13 years. Simultaneously as we try to educate the public on the necessity of total defence, we have to also impart to them the concept that defence is a life-long commitment. It is not service in the SAF for two years or 21/2 years in National Service and 10 years in the Reserve and then you are free of any responsibility whatsoever to defend this place. So we have also to preach this concept of defence is everybody's business. Defence is a life-long commitment.

    In fact, the SAF Enlistment Act clearly stipulates that Reserve liability is up to the age of 50 for officers and 40 for other ranks. Although the ideal is to require all reservists in the SAF Reserve service to serve till the maximum age limit, there are many practical limitations which preclude this ideal, factors such as lack of training area, cost of training, shortage of regular staff, administration and logistic constraints. All these limitations require us to decide on a fixed cycle for reservist training. In the past it was 10 years. So why 13 years now?

    We have been projecting future intakes into the National Service based on current and projected birth rate which has come down drastically after we started family planning. Our falling birth rate has led to dwindling National Service resources which will be insufficient for us to generate the force required for our Reserve force. If we extend this by three more years, it gives us additional men and not just additional men but also trained men for three more years. Hence the need for us to extend the training cycle from 10 to 13 years.

    As soon as a decision to increase the 10-year training cycle to 13 years was made, briefings and discussions were held by Mindef and the SAF to keep Reservist officers informed of the new Reserve policy. The respective Reserve Formation Headquarters also conducted briefings for their Reserve personnel. Mindef is happy to note that reservists have no problem accepting the logic for the extension from a 10-year Reserve cycle to 13 years.

Column: 1190


3.00 pm

    What about the employers? Would this not inconvenience the employers even though most of the reservists understand the need for an extended reserve cycle? Mindef has also held meetings with employers to explain the rationale for increasing the Reserve cycle from 10 to 13 years. Mindef is also pleased to note that more and more employers are coming forward to express their support for their employees' involvement in Reserve in-camp training and for the need for total defence. In fact, if employers have been accustomed to the reservists going for in-camp training for the last 10 years, an additional three years will not pose any great inconvenience to the companies.

    A question was asked as to the criteria for enlistment into National Service. The Enlistment Act provides for all able-bodied citizens to render National Service. The contribution or the role he will play in the defence of Singapore will, however, to a larger extent, depend on the physical standard and educational attainment as well as the vocational requirements of National Service appointments. Those who satisfy the criteria for enlistment into full National Service, which I have touched on above, would serve in any one of the organizations which require full-time National Service, like the Singapore Armed Forces, Police National Service and so on.

    If the Member for Kaki Bukit knows of any particular able-bodied citizens who have not served National Service and who would like to do so, we would be pleased to get the names from him.

    Moving on to the question raised by the Member for Nee Soon on the quality of SAF officers and how we intend to upgrade the quality to meet new needs, this question was also touched on by the Member for Pasir Panjang when he spoke on the Regular officers. I will take both questions together. We need to do two things. The first thing is to recruit better and better qualified individuals who can become officers or NCOs. That is the first approach, to work out a scheme to attract better qualified people to join the SAF. Secondly, for those who are in the Regular

Column: 1191

service, we have to work out schemes to upgrade the quality of these officers and NCOs.

    Fundamental to the upgrading of the SAF officer cadre is our ability to identify those who have good potential and to groom them for key appointments. First, we have to identify them before we can groom them. The SAF has a Wrangler scheme which was started in February 1974 to achieve this. This scheme was revised in July 1981 to incorporate elements of the Shell appraisal scheme. The scheme is part of a wider personnel management system for assessing and developing SAF officers. Basic to the system is the SAF personnel management philosophy of developing human resources to the fullest of the individual's potential. That is the fundamental assumption in the management philosophy. Fitting the right man to the right job at the right time is not only good for the man, but it is also good for the SAF.

    Apart from the Wrangler development scheme, the SAF also runs advanced and specialized military courses to keep all its officers and NCOs updated and trained in modern weaponry and tactics. In FY 1983, a total of 1,083 regulars, 465 national servicemen and 589 reservists attended advanced level courses conducted by the SAF. Sixty-three regular officers and 28 regular NCOs were also sent overseas to attend specialized courses conducted by other armed forces so that they could learn from their experience and to ensure that in-breeding does not occur.

    To improve the quality of the officer cadre, the SAF revised the minimum educational requirement for its Regular recruits in 1981. Officers are required to have a minimum of two 'A' levels and two 'O' levels. To ensure that the SAF has its fair share of top talent, the SAF has scholarship schemes to sponsor good 'A' level students to the best universities overseas as well as to the NUS. Ten candidates were awarded the SAF Overseas Scholarship in 1982 and 12 in 1983 to study in Oxbridge and other good universities in the United Kingdom. Fourteen candidates were awarded scholarships to pursue both academic and military training in military

Column: 1192

academies in UK, Japan, West Germany and Australia. Another 20 National Service officers took up local scholarships to study in the NUS in 1983. There are several other management courses which we put our SAF officers and NCOs through.

    To ensure that the SAF is able to attract and retain a fair share of the requisite skills and talents, the terms and conditions of service are continually being reviewed to keep them competitive with those prevailing in the public sector as well as in the private sector. We have set up a Pay Research Unit recently to better organize research into salaries and service conditions. The salaries of SAF officers are presently being pegged at 20% above those in the Civil Service for candidates with similar abilities and capabilities. This is also in recognition of military life being more onerous and demanding.

    As for welfare schemes, there are several such schemes which are available to the Regular officers, like housing loans, car loans, and so on. I do not think I need go into details of these schemes which are sufficiently attractive to the Regular officers and NCOs.

    What is the status of the drug problem in the SAF? This was asked by the Member for Nee Soon. The problem of drug abuse in the SAF has been well contained. That explains our silence, not the other way round. Evidence? The number of servicemen arrested for drug offences decreased from 631 cases in 1977 to only 109 cases last year, hard evidence that the problem is under control. The relapse rate for drug abuses has also dropped steadily over the last five years. In 1977, there were 90 cases of relapse. In 1983, only 34 cases. How have we done this? Again, we adopt a two-prong approach, soft and hard approaches. The soft approach comprises various educational an d publicity measures carried out from the very beginning when the servicemen are enlisted. The purpose of the programme is to educate them on the dangers of drug abuse. Counsellors from the SAF Counselling Centre assist unit officers in this educational effort. Servicemen who have taken drugs prior to their enlistment are encouraged to admit this fact to their superiors or medical officers. Disciplinary

Column: 1193

action will not be taken against self-confessed drug abusers.

    In addition to education and publicity, more direct preventive and containment measures are taken to discourage abuse in the SAF. Mass urine screening exercises are regularly conducted on a spot-check basis at unit level. Where abusers persist in their drug taking habit, punitive punishment follows. Even then the emphasis is on counselling and prevention. Every effort is made by the SAF to rehabilitate drug abusers. Even where punitive punishment has been meted out against persistent drug abusers, they are accorded individual attention and treatment from counsellors from the SAF Counselling Centre which has a good record in tackling the drug problem in the SAF.
3.15 pm

    The Member for Nee Soon also touched on the peculiar procedure in SAF of requiring national servicemen who have fallen sick and seen private doctors to personally submit their medical certificates to the SAF units within 24 hours. This is, in fact, the directive but I have been told that officers exercise this flexibly.     In his haste to find fault with Government statistics, the Member for Anson has got himself completely mixed up. When this is done using the figures in Table 2.1 of the Economic Survey as quoted by the Member for Anson, he would find that real value-added per worker in 1983 expressed in 1981 prices was $36,669 compared with $34,419 in 1981.
